turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: But with Rogers and his house of hacks gone, you'd make the rules.  Just think it over.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Please try to understand, Terence. I've already made up my mind.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: It was her voice.  On the radio.  It was Jamie.  Calling for me.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: You don't know that for sure.  It could have been anyone.  A practical joke. Kids.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: It was Jamie Lloyd.  She came back, as I knew she would one day.  And whatever has brought her back has brought Michael back as well.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: After six years?  Sam, she died with him in that explosion after the --

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: That's what someone wants us to believe, but I tell you Michael is alive.  I feel him.  I sense the evil that lives inside, just as I did all those years as I watched him.  Sitting behind these very same walls.  Staring. Growing stronger.  As my colleague, as my friend, please. I can't go through this again.  Not alone.  I need your help to stop him.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Notify Haddonfield's sheriff; tell him we're on our way.  I want the entire staff on alert.  We go to code red lockdown for twenty-four hours.  If he is alive, I plan on bringing him back.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Or what's left of him.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: It's a sign.  He's come home.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Sam, don't -- let them take care of her.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I'm here now, Jamie.  You're going to live. You have to.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: There you are.  Who was that boy?

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: An old friend.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: There's more people moving eastbound down Old Reservoir Road past the elementary school.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Any word on the location of the Strodes?

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: No one's home.  Checked it out myself.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Good.  I want around-the-clock surveillance on that house.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: What's wrong?  What's happened to Jamie?

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: I'll meet you over there.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Where's the child?

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Sam, you know you never fail to amaze me.  Yesterday happily retired, today right back in the thick of things. Somehow I knew you still had it in you.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Come now, Sam.  This is a gathering of old friends.  I know how difficult this must be for you -- a man of your upbringing and integrity -- but now that I'm in charge I felt it was only fair that you finally know the truth.  After all, you're the only one around here who's still in the dark, as it were.  This isn't the way I wanted to tell you, but you've really given me no other choice.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: This is madness, Wynn.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Your madness is another man's greatness.  This is the way things have always been.  You've just been too blinded by your own reality to see.  But having you on the outside has been convenient for us in many ways.  You always did come through -- our loyal watch dog. Finding him. Bringing him back to us once he'd finished his work.  Although after you had that nasty stroke the last time, I had to go after him myself.  And what a terrible time we had getting him out of that jail cell.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: It was you.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Why did you take Jamie?

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: She has the gift -- the blood of Thorn running through her veins.  Michael's mother had it, too.  So for six years I incubated her, prepared her for this night.  Michael has served his purpose.  And soon we will have a new progeny.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Jamie's baby ...

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: There you go trying to make sense again.  It's a curse.  Handed down through countless generations. As ageless as this celebration which you call Halloween.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Samhain.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: And I'm its deliverer.  Its calling card, if you will.  I follow it.  Protect it. Act as its guardian.  In a sense, Sam, so do you.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: You've created a monster.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Amazing, isn't it?  I even taught him to drive.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: No!!!

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Stay away, Sam.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Leave the boy.  Take me.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Dr. Loomis, thank God you're here.  You heard her, didn't you?  It was Jamie.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I'm sorry, but do I know you --

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I'm Tommy.  Tommy Doyle.  Laurie Strode -- Jamie's mother -- she was baby-sitting for me that night --

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Yes ... Tommy.  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Please -- just tell me the truth.  Has Michael Myers come home?

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: What do you know about Michael?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I know he's alive.  People in this town -- they want us to believe he's dead.  But I know. I've always known.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Right now at least one girl is dead and Jamie Lloyd is in there fighting for her life.  She is the last of his blood line.  If she dies --

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No, Dr. Loomis.  She's not the last night.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Who else knew I had the baby?!

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: No one.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No -- there had to be someone else. Who knew?!

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Only me --  -- and Dr. Wynn.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Run, Tommy!!!  Run!!!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No!!!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Miss me, baby?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno, boy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: It's a bitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: A bitch.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Didn't recognize you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We've never met.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I wonder who'll recognize us first? They'll wet their pants.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I hope the men do.  I would rather the women didn't.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I'm gonna wet my pants.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Home, sweet home.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: One thing, anyway--at least Penelope didn't throw out all your crap.  I bet Alice threw out all my crap after I'd been gone a week.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We'll see.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It appears that we're going to have to wait awhile for any more action here, Colonel.  Why don't you run on home while the evening's young.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Home.  Jesus.  I'm like this.  Home!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Home is important to a man.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: How all the magazines show tits today.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Used to be against the law, didn't it?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I suppose.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Must have changed that law.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh, shit.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: How everybody says "fuck" and "shit" all the time.  I used to be scared shitless I'd say "fuck" or "shit" in public, by accident.  Now everybody says "fuck" and "shit," "fuck" and "shit" all the time. Something very big must have happened while we were out of the country.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Looseleaf--will you get the hell home?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: At least we found the diamonds.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: At least!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I'd really feel stupid if we didn't bring anything back home.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's enough that you've brought yourself home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I wish you'd tell Alice that.  And that Goddamn Mrs. Wheeler.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Tell them yourself!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You don't know my mother-in-law, boy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: After eight years in the jungle with you, I know Mrs. Wheeler better than I know anybody in the universe!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I didn't tell you everything.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The time we were in a tree for fourteen days, you certainly tried to tell me everything about Mrs. Wheeler.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I didn't even scratch the surface. You're lucky, boy.  You come home, and nobody's here.  When I go home, everybody's going to be there.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This room is full of ghosts.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You're lucky, boy.  My house is gonna be filled with people.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Thank God we found the fucking diamonds!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The hell with the diamonds!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You were rich before.  This is the first time I was ever rich.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go home!  Show them how rich you are for a change!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Can I have the Cadillac?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Take the Cadillac and drive it off a cliff, for all I care.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: What'll you do for transportation?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'll buy a hundred more Cadillacs. Go home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me about that Cadillac?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: When I drive it, I feel like I'm in the middle of a great big wad of bubblegum.  I don't hear anything, I don't feel anything.  I figure somebody else is driving.  It's a bitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go home.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I'm liable to find anything!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's the point!  Walk in there and find whatever there is to find--before Alice can cover it up.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I know, I know.  I dunno.  At least she's in the same house.  Sure was spooky, looking in the window there, and there she was.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: So long, Colonel.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Let's talk about it some other time.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: How short the skirts are.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Good night, Colonel.  It's been beautiful.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Something very important about sex must have happened while we were gone.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know what gets me?  Those guys who went to the moon!  To the moon, boy!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Leave me alone!  After eight years of horrendously close association, the time has come to part!  I crave solitude and time for reflection-- and then a reunion in privacy with my own flesh and blood.  You and I may not meet again for months!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Months?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm certainly not going to come horning back into your life tomorrow, and I will not welcome your horning back into mine.  A chapter has ended.  We are old comrades--at a parting of the ways.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I'm lonesome already.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I've been looking at motorcycles.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You ever own a motorcycle?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're right!  We'll take a trip. A trip is what we'll take.  I don't want to talk about motorcycles.  I don't want to talk about tits.  Go home!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Haven't got one.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And how were things?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Let's talk about something else.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Otherwise, how are things?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I sure didn't expect her to drop dead.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Could have happened to anybody.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: First Nagasaki--now this.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How about breakfast, wife?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno, boy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The educational process.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I guess.  You're lucky you don't have any old people around here.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She was about to get married again. She locked me out of the bedroom last night.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's funny about that?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You know me, boy.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: One of them is the doctor, whose weapons are compassion, unselfishness, peacefulness-- maudlin concern.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He and his love are like a retiarius.  Do you know what a retiarius is?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: He's a kind of gladiator who fights with a knife and a net and doesn't wear anything but a jockstrap.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You told me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: When we were up in the tree so long--with the bats.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh.  I'd forgotten.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Fourteen times you told me.  I counted.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You'd get this funny look in your eyes, and I'd say to myself, "Oh, Jesus--he's going to tell me what a retiarius is again."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Go to the funeral?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Of course!  Not only go to it but go to it in full uniform!  Rent a uniform!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: That's against the law, isn't it? I can't wear a uniform anymore.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Wear your uniform and every decoration, and let them despise you, if they dare.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Alice would be absolutely tear-ass.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: When I was a naive young recruit in Spain, I used to wonder why soldiers bayoneted oil paintings, shot the noses off of statues and defecated into grand pianos.  I now understand: It was to teach civilians the deepest sort of respect for men in uniform-- uncontrollable fear.  To our women.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I didn't know we had any women left.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The world is teeming with women-- ours to enjoy.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Every time I start thinking like that I get the clap.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I told you the uniform wouldn't help.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It helped more than you know.  Down deep, people were deeply affected.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You keep on saying "deep" and "deeply." I wish something good would happen on the surface sometime.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: So, kid--how they hanging?  Or don't you say that to a little kid?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He's a man.  Tell him you're a man.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Of course you'll go!  You're going to fly the helicopter.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're so low!  Look at that beautiful red meat.  You haven't touched it.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Sorry.  At least you've got a place to come back to.  I don't have a place to come back to anymore.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: All the more reason to go to Africa.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno. You know.  I used to really love that Alice. Do you know that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You know her for what she is now-- garbage.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She was always a rotten wife!  She was against everything manly you ever wanted to do.  He was the most daring test pilot in the country at one time, and his wife made him quit.  She made him become a life insurance salesman instead.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Hi, Penelope.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Shut up, you ninny!  You were never to come here again-- for any reason whatsoever!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go live in a safe-deposit box--with your things. LOOSELEAF Jesus--I wouldn't want to be married to him.  You know?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I wouldn't want to be married to me. We're too crazy.  You know?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: In what way, pray tell?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I didn't like that violin thing. That was sad.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Tit for tat--as simple as that.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: You never played a violin.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Yeah.  I practically forgot.  But after you busted that thing, I got to thinking, "Jesus--maybe I'll start the violin again." That didn't just belong to Woodly.  That belonged to everybody.  Maybe he would have sold it to me, and I could have some fun.  After you busted the violin, boy, and Penelope walked out, I thought to myself, "Jesus--who could blame her?"

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Maybe it's time you got out.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Okay.  Okay.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're an imbecile.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I know you think that.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Everybody thinks that.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Anybody who'd drop an atom bomb on a city has to be pretty dumb.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The one direct, decisive, intelligent act of your life!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I don't think so.  It could have been.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If what?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: If I hadn't done it.  If I'd said to myself, "Screw it.  I'm going to let all those people down there live."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: They were enemies.  We were at war.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Yeah, Jesus--but wars would be a lot better, I think, if guys would say to themselves sometimes, "Jesus--I'm not going to do that to the enemy.  That's too much." You could have been the manufacturer of that violin there, even though you don't know how to make a violin, just by not busting it up.  I could have been the father of all those people in Nagasaki, and the mother, too, just by not dropping the bomb.  I sent 'em to Heaven instead--and I don't think there is one.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Goodbye, Looseleaf.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How are you, honeybunch?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Is Penelope in?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The posies are for her?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I wanted to apologize.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You've come to the right man.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I forgot my vacuum cleaner.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I forget mine for years on end.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Oh my God--  And you are Looseleaf Harper.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I can't get over how you guys are my friends.  Harold Ryan and Looseleaf Harper are my friends.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Our pleasure.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Eight years you guys were together-- through thick and thin.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: For seven and a half of those years we were heavily drugged--or we would have been home long before now, believe me.  We were saved from starvation by the Lupi-Loopo Indians, who fed us a strange blue soup.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Blue soup.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It sapped our will--made us peaceful and unenterprising.  It was a form of chemical castration. We became two more sleepy Indians.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Are we really going to find out where the elephants go to die?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd rather go to Viet Nam.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Would somebody please pass me the catsup?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What you say is, "Pass the fucking catsup."

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Pass the fucking catsup.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Insurance!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You actually sold insurance!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: What an awful sound!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Get used to it.  Back door, Paul.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's possible, of course, that you'll die in Africa.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I've considered that.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Selling vacuum cleaners isn't the best preparation you could have.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I just want one true adventure before I die.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That can be arranged.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Fifty years?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You're making a joke.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm interested in long-term expectations.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: It's engineered to last about fifteen years.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Things.  Oh--you silly people and your things.  Things, things, things.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: If I were married to him, I sure wouldn't walk out.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Never mind the condition of your body and your spirit!  Look after your things, your things!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Who's going to fly our helicopter now?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: We got to get another pilot.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: For Africa.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Do you really think that Harold Ryan would go to Africa with a vacuum cleaner salesman?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You invited me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: To make an ass of yourself.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: What went wrong?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We're ahead of schedule, that's all. You're finding out here what you would have found out in Africa-- that you are a rabbit, born to be eaten alive.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Gee whiz--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It would have been fun to see you drop your rifle and run the first time an elephant charged us.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I wouldn't drop my gun.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're hollow, like a woman.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I'm smarter than Looseleaf.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He can shoot!  He can hold his ground!  He can attack!  You're in your proper profession right now-- sucking up dirt for frumpish housewives, closet drunkards every one.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: How do you know how I'd act in Africa?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look how you're acting now!  This is a moment of truth, and you're almost crying.  Slug me!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You're my buddy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Out!  Out!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: No matter what you say to me, I still think you're the greatest guy I ever knew.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Out!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You--you aren't going to have any friends left, if you don't watch out.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank God!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Anybody home?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: As a matter of fact--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: As a matter of fact--I am home.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You were about to ask a question?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you--do you--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ask it!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you know who Wanda June is?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Life has denied me that thrill.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you mind if I ask who you are?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mind?  God, yes, I mind.  I'm your father's friend.  A man claiming to be the family physician let me in a while ago.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dr. Woodly.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Dr. Woodly.  I should make a little list.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Is anybody besides you here now?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The doctor was called away on an emergency.  I think it was birth.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Where's Mom?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You don't know where your mother is? Does she put on a short skirt and go drinking all night?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She went to the fight with Herb Shuttle, I guess.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You think you could find me a pencil and paper?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'll see.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And you've been roaming the streets while your mother is God-knows-where?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I was going to a funny movie, but I changed my mind.  If you're depressed, laughing doesn't help much.  When did you know my father?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Man and boy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Everybody says he was so brave.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Even this--"Herb Shuttle", you said?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He worships Father.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ah!  And what sort of man is this worshiper?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He's a vacuum cleaner salesman.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I see.  And he came into the apartment one day, to demonstrate his wares, and your mother, as it happened, was charmingly en deshabille--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She met him at college.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: College!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They were in the same creative writing class.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: College?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She has a master's degree in English literature.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What a pity!  Educating a beautiful woman is like pouring honey into a fine Swiss watch.  Everything stops.  And the doctor?  He worships your father, too?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He insults him all the time.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Excellent!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What's good about that?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It makes life spicy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He doesn't do it in front of me, but he does it with Mother.  You know what he called Father one time?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: "Harold, the Patron Saint of Taxidermy."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What does he do--of an athletic nature?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Nothing.  He plays a violin in a doctors' quartet.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Aha!  He has a brilliant military record, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He was a stretcher-bearer in the Korean War.  Were you in a war with Father?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Big ones, little ones, teeny-weeny ones--just and otherwise.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Tell me some true stories about Dad.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: "Dad?"  Dad.  The boy wants tales of derring-do. Name a country.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: England?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh hell.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dad was never in England?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Behind a desk for a little while.  A desk!  They had him planning air raids.  A city can't flee like a coward or fight like a man, and the choice between fleeing and fighting was at the core of the life of Harold Ryan.  There was only one thing he enjoyed more than watching someone make that choice, and that was making the choice himself.  Ask about Spain, where he was the youngest soldier in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.  He was a famous sniper.  They called him "La Picadura"--"the sting."

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: "The sting."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: As in "Death, where is thy sting?" He killed at least fifty men, wounded hundreds more.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: "The sting."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ask about the time he and I were parachuted into Yugoslavia to join a guerrilla band--in the war against the Nazis.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Tell me that.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I saw your father fight Major Siegfried von Konigswald, the Beast of Yugoslavia, hand to hand.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Tell me that!  Tell me that!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hid by day--fought by night.  At sunset one day, your father and I, peering through field glasses, saw a black Mercedes draw up to a village inn.  It was escorted by two motorcyclists and an armored car.  Out of the Mercedes stepped one of the most hateful men in all of history--the Beast of Yugoslavia.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We blacked our hands and faces.  At midnight we crept out of the forest and into the village.  The name of the village was Mhravitch. Remember that name!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Mhravitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We came up behind a sentry, and your father slit his throat before he could utter a sound.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uck.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't care for cold steel?  A knife is worse than a bullet?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The story gets hairier.  Should I stop?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We caught another Kraut alone in a back lane.  Your father choked him to death with a length of piano wire.  Your father was quite a virtuoso with piano wire.  That's nicer than a knife, isn't it--as long as you don't look at the face afterwards.  The face turns a curious shade of avocado.  I must ask the doctor why that is.  At any rate, we stole into the back of the inn, and, with the permission of the management, we poisoned the wine of six Krauts who were carousing there.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Where did you get the poison?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We carried cyanide capsules.  We were supposed to swallow them in case we were captured.  It was your father's opinion that the Krauts needed them more than we did at the time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And one of them was the Beast of Yugoslavia? HAROLD The Beast was upstairs, and he came running downstairs, for his men were making loud farewells and last wills and testaments--editorializing about the hospitality they had received.  And your father said to him in perfect German, which he had learned in the Spanish Civil War, "Major, something tragic seems to have happened to your bodyguard.  I am Harold Ryan, of the United States of America.  You, I believe, are the Beast of Yugoslavia."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mhravitch.  Remember that name.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Mhravitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The name will live forever.  It was there that Harold Ryan slew the Beast of Yugoslavia.  Mhravitch.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: When I grow up, I'm going to go to Mhravitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's rather a disappointment these days.  It isn't there any more.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The Germans shot everybody who lived there, then leveled it, plowed it, planted turnips and cabbages in the fertile ground. They wished revenge for the slaying of the Beast of Yugoslavia.  To their twisted way of thinking, your father had butchered an Eagle Scout.  Play lots of contact sports?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I wanted to go out for football, but Mom was afraid I'd get hurt.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're supposed to get hurt!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dr. Woodly says he's seen hundreds of children permanently injured by football.  He says that when there's a war, everybody goes but football players.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Does it bother you to have your mother engaged to a man like that?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They're not engaged.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He seems to think they are.  He told me that were.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh no, no, no, no, no.  It can't be. How embarrassing.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're a very good boy to respond that way.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, no, no, no, no.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd like to use the sanitary facilities, if I may.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Go ahead.  No, no, no, no.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes, wife, it is.  Come here, boy.  Your father is home.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Wants to fix up her makeup, no doubt.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Is Looseleaf Harper alive?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Alive and hale.  He's throwing a little surprise party for his own family.  Is your mother often this unstable?  Penelope!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She's a real heavy sleeper sometimes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Why don't you go to bed--son.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I can't take my eyes off you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Tomorrow's another day. PAUL You know what my English literature teacher said about you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Can't it keep till morning?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She said you were legendary.  I wrote a theme about you, and she said, "Your father is a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's nice.  You thank her for me. Go to bed and get lots of sleep, and then you thank her in the morning.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Tomorrow's Saturday.  Anyway, she's dead.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Penelope!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She was killed in the park two months ago--in the daytime.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Penelope!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She was on her way home from a meeting of the African Violet Society, and they got her.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Will you go to bed?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yes sir.  If you can't wake Mom up, I've got double-decker bunks.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Scat!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dad's got jungle fever, Mom. What'll I do?  Mom!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Play?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Your mother and I do not wish to be disturbed for three full hours.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A hundred dollars!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The smallest thing I've got.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Can I get dressed first?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Make it fast.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dad--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Couldn't you have vanished quietly out the back door?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A hundred dollars for breakfast?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Leave a tip.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What kind of exercise?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Beat the shit out of someone who hates you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm a man.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We've got to do something to make this boy's voice change.  I wonder if we couldn't get bull balls somewhere, and fry 'em up.  Still miss your mother?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're free to go to her, if you want.  If you'd rather be a woman and run with the women, just say the word.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dad?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Who was it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's Mom.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's a rifle you have?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Of course it is.  Is it loaded?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Open the bolt!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's a cartridge, if I'm not mistaken.  Gunpowder, bullet, cartridge case, and fulminate of mercury percussion cap--all set to go. PAUL I was cleaning it.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Pick up that cartridge and slip it back into the chamber--where it belongs.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Gee whiz, Dad--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Welcome to manhood, you little sparrowfart!  Load that gun!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dad--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Too late!  It's man to man now. Protecting your mother from me, are you?  Protect her!`

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Then speak, by God!  Can you fight with words?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't want to fight you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Get mad!  Tell me you don't like the way I treat your mother!  Tell me you wish I'd never come home!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's your house, Dad.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Everybody simply evaporates!  There are guest issues to be fought out here--or to be argued, at least. The enemy, the champion of all who oppose me, is in East St. Louis with his mother and his aunt!  I have so far done battle with a woman and a child and a violin.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know what I hope.  But I don't think you care what I hope, anyway.  You don't know me.  You don't know her, either.  I don't think you know anybody.  You talk to everybody just the same.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm talking to you gently now.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.  But it's going to get loud again.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How do you do.  My name is Penelope Ryan.  This is a simple-minded play about men who enjoy killing--and those who don't.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I am Harold Ryan, her husband.  I have killed perhaps two hundred men in wars of various sorts--as a professional soldier.  I have killed thousands of other animals as well--for sport.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: "Hamburger Heaven."

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Heaven.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Can I help you, sir?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I think so, daughter.  How old are you?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Eighteen--  and a half.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: A springbok, an oryx, a gemsbok--a gazelle.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Raw hamburger, please--and a whole onion.  I want to eat the onion like an apple.  Do you understand?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  It was a very unusual automobile. It was a Cadillac, but it had water buffalo horns where the bumpers should be.  And what to drink?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What time do you get off work, my child?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir, I'm engaged to be married.  My boyfriend would be mad if I went out with another man.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Did you ever daydream that you would one day meet a friendly millionaire?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm engaged.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Daughter--I love you very much.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You don't even know me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You are woman.  I know woman well.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: This is crazy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Destiny often seems that way. You're going to marry me.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What do you do for a living?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: My parents died in an automobile accident when I was sixteen years old.  They left me a brewery and a baseball team--and other things.  I live for a living.  I've just come back from Kenya--in Africa.  I've been hunting Mau Mau there.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Some kind of animal?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The pelt is black.  It's a kind of man.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How do you do, Mrs. Ryan?  I'd heard you were beautiful, and so you are.  Am I intruding here?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I couldn't help overhearing that you were about to get married again.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Give us time.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Like hugging a lamp post.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Give us time, Harold--to adjust to your being alive.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You were well adjusted to my being dead?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We adjust to what there is to adjust to.  Perhaps Paul, being young, can adjust to joy or grief immediately.  I hope he can.  I will take a little longer.  I'll be as quick as I can.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What sort of time period do you have in mind?  Half an hour?  An hour?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I don't know.  This is a new disease to me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Disease?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Situation.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This reunion isn't what I imagined it would be.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A telegram--a phone call might have helped.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Seemed the most honest way to begin life together again--natural, unrehearsed.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Well--enjoy the natural, honest, unrehearsed result--surgical shock.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You feel that you're behaving as a woman should?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Every fuse in my nervous system has been blown.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Bluh.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You'd better get Dr. Woodly.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's that all about?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We thought a doctor might help.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Your old beau?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We thought it was an emergency.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't want that chancre mechanic in here.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's a very decent man, Harold.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We all are.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Shouldn't you lie down?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: When I'm dead--  or fucking.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Paul said you were awfully sick.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I was, I was.  It never lasts long.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You know what I want?  I want you both to be friends.  I know you both, respect you both. You should be friends.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Nothing would please me more.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Thank God!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm so glad you like each other.  I was so scared, so scared.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Have some.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Harold!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I could carve a better man out of a banana!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Please--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You and your damned bedside manner and your damned little black bag full of miracles.  You know who filled that bag for you?  Not Alice-sit-by-the-fires like yourself.  Men with guts filled it, by God--men with guts enough to pay the price for miracles--suffering, ingratitude, loneliness, death--

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He doesn't deserve this!  You don't know him.  It isn't fair!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He thought he could take my place. It is now my privilege to give an unambiguous account of why I don't think he's man enough to do that.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Awful.  I can't tell you how sorry I am.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Say hello to your mother.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Do say hello to your mother.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Now that's what I call fun.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Ghastly, cruel, unnecessary.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You'll get so you enjoy twitting weaklings again.  You used to eat it up.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I did?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We were one hell of a pair--and we'll be one again.  What we need is a honeymoon.  Let's start right now.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A trip, you mean?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I had a trip.  We'll honeymoon here.  Go out and play.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He hasn't had breakfast yet.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Buy yourself breakfast.  There we go.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Honeymoon!  Honeymoon!  Say it: Honeymoon!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's so--so stark.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You used to like it stark!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Just--bang--we have a honeymoon.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm not going to strike you.  I am going to be as gentle as pie--as lemon meringue pie.  You mustn't run away now.  This is your loving husband approaching.  I'm your husband.  Society approves!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Now--turn around, if you would.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Turn around?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm not about to introduce to you a jungle novelty.  What I have in mind is massage--a perfectly decent massage.  Turn around, turn around.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm going to touch your shoulders very gently now.  You mustn't scream.  So tense, so tense.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You shouldn't have talked to Norbert that way.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're thinking with your brain instead of your body.  That's why you're so tense!  Forget Norbert. Relax.  It's body time.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I have a brain.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We all do.  But now it's body time. Relax.  Ideally, the body of a woman should feel like a hot water bottle filled with Devonshire cream. You feel like a paper bag crammed with curtain rods.  Think of your muscles one by one.  Let them go slack.  Relax.  Let the brain go blank.  Relax.  That's the idea-- that's my girl.  Now the small of the back.  Let those knots over those kidneys unsnarl.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I have some change!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ram it up your ass!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Breakfast?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Scrambled eggs, kippered herring, fried potatoes--and a whole onion. I want to eat the onion like an apple.  Do you understand?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And lots of orange juice--oceans of orange juice.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Mrs. Wheeler is dead.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: All right--bring me a side order of Mrs. Wheeler.  Oh, hell--sit down, Colonel. Penelope will bring you some chow.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That is the most heartless statement I ever heard pass between human lips.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Which one?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: "Bring me a side order of Mrs. Wheeler."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She's up in Heaven now.  She didn't hear.  She is experiencing nothing but pure happiness.  There's nothing nicer than that.  Chow!  Harold Ryan wants chow!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What a honeymoon.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Honeymoon temporarily canceled.  The boy should still go out and exercise.  I have the impression he never gets any exercise.  He simply bloats himself with Fig Newtons and bakes his brains over steam radiators.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You're wrong.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Then let me see him go out and get some exercise.  Right now!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Chow, chow, chow!  God damn it-- nutriment!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We're all going to have to go out for breakfast.  The cook quit yesterday.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're a woman, aren't you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Cook, by God!  Cook!  You're the nigger now.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: People don't use that word any more.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't lecture me on race relations. I don't have a molecule of prejudice.  I've been in battle with every kind of man there is. I've been in bed with every kind of woman there is--from a Laplander to a Tierra del Fuegian. If I'd ever been to the South Pole, there'd be a hell of a lot of penguins who looked like me.  Cook!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You leave me so--so without-- without dignity.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: People now have dignity when frying eggs?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: They don't have to feel like slaves.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Then go now--and fry with dignity-- sunnyside up.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I should have torn that door off its hinges.  Should have scrogged her ears off.  Should have broken the bed.  What do you want?  Well?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I--I was wondering--is there anything you shouldn't eat--because of jungle fever?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I could eat a raw baby crocodile.  The way to get your wife back is in bed.  Do such a job on her that she'll be lucky if she can crawl around on all fours.  We're starving.  Do you mind?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Let me guess--breakfast is served?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What then?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I do not wish to be scrogged--ever. I never heard that word, but when I heard it, I knew it was one thing I never wanted to have happen to me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's what you're supposed to say.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You don't know you want.  That's the way God built you!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I will not be scrogged.  I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It couldn't!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Fish can't feel.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more.  Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Such as?...

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Tell me about its sexual roots.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say--  for revenge.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You learned this in some college course?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The doctor.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And what is his most cherished possession?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: His most cherished possession?  His violin, I guess.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And he keeps it in his apartment?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And no one's there now?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No you're not!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Because if you do--I'll leave you. HAROLD  Goodbye.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I came for my clothes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Sneaking in the back door.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I rang.  It seemed like the proper door for a servile, worthless organism to use.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Your clothes are at the city dump by now.  Perhaps you can get a map from the Department of Sanitation.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I came for Paul as well.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If he wants to go.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You took him to the funeral, I hear.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He'd never seen a corpse.  He's seen a dozen now.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A dozen?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's a big and busy funeral home.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Did you like it, dear?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It isn't a matter of liking.  It's a matter of getting used to death-- as a perfectly natural thing. Would you mind leaving?  No woman ever walks out on Harold Ryan, and then comes back--for anything.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Unless she has nerve.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: More nerve than the doctor, I must admit.  He hasn't been home for two days.  Has he suddenly lost interest in sleep and color television--and the violin?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He knows you shattered his violin.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm dying to hear of his reaction. The thrill of smashing something isn't in the smashing, but in the owner's reactions.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He cried.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: About a broomstick and a cigar box--and the attenuated intestines of an alley cat.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Two hundred years old.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He feels awful loss--which was precisely my intention.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He had hoped that someone would be playing it still--two hundred years from now.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hope.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Things.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You feel I've done a dreadful thing--leaving him?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well--what have we here?  A family.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Almost a Christmas scene.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Goodbye, goodbye, goodbye.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Just one favor.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Money?  There's plenty of that. Mildred got the brewery.  You'll probably get the baseball team.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I want you to tell me that you loved me once.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Testimonials of that sort are--are beyond my range.  I don't do them well.  That's a failing, I know.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: See how you've upset him.  He was so merry and hale before you came home.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How unhappy he's going to be--alone in his room.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He'll play with his rifle, I expect. That will cheer him up.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Rifle?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I bought him a twenty-two yesterday--on the way home from Hamburger Heaven.  And where is the good doctor?  Have you two feathered a love nest somewhere?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's in East St. Louis with his mother--visiting an aunt.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Last I heard, his mother was going alone.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's afraid of you, Harold.  He knew you'd want to fight him.  He doesn't know anything about fighting.  He hates pain.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And you, a supposedly healthy woman, do not detest him for his cowardice?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It seems highly intelligent to me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What kind of a country has this become?  The men wear beads and refuse to fight--and the woman adore them.  America's days of greatness are over.  It has drunk the blue soup.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Blue soup?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: An Indian narcotic we were forced to drink.  It put us in a haze--a honey-colored haze which was lavender around the edge.  We laughed, we sang, we snoozed.  When a bird called, we answered back. Every living thing was our brother or our sister, we thought. Looseleaf stepped on a cockroach six inches long, and we cried.  We had a funeral that went on for five days--for the cockroach!  I sang "Oh Promise Me." Can you imagine? Where the hell did I ever learn the words to "Oh Promise Me"?  Looseleaf delivered a lecture on maintenance procedures for the hydraulic system of a B-36.  All the time we were drinking more blue soup, more blue soup!  Never stopped drinking blue soup.  Blue soup all the time. We'd go out after food in that honey-colored haze, and everything that was edible had a penumbra of lavender.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Sounds quite beautiful.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Beautiful, you say?  It wasn't life, it wasn't death--it wasn't anything!  Beautiful?  Seven years gone--  like that, like that!  Seven years of silliness and random dreams! Seven years of nothingness, when there could have been so much!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Action!  Interaction!  Give and take!  Challenge and response!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's a child!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: With an iron penis three feet long. Load it, boy.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You're begging him to kill you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If he thinks he's man enough.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That's really what you want.  You become furious when people won't make you dead.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm teaching my son to be a man.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: So he can kill you.  You hate your own life that much.  You beg for a hero to kill you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I plan to live one hundred years!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No you don't.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If that's the case--what's to prevent my killing myself?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Honor, I suppose.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What a handsome word.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: But it's all balled up in your head with death.  The highest honor is death.  When you talk of these animals, one by one, you don't just talk of killing them.  You honored them with death.  Harold--it is not honor to be killed.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If you've lived a good life, fought well--

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's still just death, the absence of life--no honor at all.  It's worse than the blue soup by far-- that nothingness.  To you, though, it's the honor that crowns them all.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: May I continue with the rearing of my son?  Load that gun!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: The old heroes are going to have to get used to this, Harold--the new heroes who refuse to fight. They're trying to save the planet. There's no time for battle, no point to battle anymore.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I feel mocked, insulted, with no sort of satisfaction in prospect. We don't have to fight with steel. I can fight with words.  I'm not an inarticulate ape, you know, who grabs a rock for want of a vocabulary.  Call him up in East St. Louis, Penelope.  Tell him to come here.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And my son, the only son of Harold Ryan--he's going to grow up to be a vanisher, too?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I don't know.  I hope he never hunts.  I hope he never kills another human being.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You hope this, too?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm going to call the police.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: This is suicide.  Go get the police.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Stop!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No, we won't.  No matter how it begins, it will end in death. Because it always does.  Isn't that always how it ends, Harold--in death?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: There has to be a threat of some sort, nobility of some sort, glamour of some sort, sport of some sort.  These elements are lacking.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm turning off the alarm.  I'm turning off everything.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ah!  The lady is armed.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I want you to get out of here, Norbert.  Harold--I want you to sit down in the chair, and not lift a finger until Norbert is gone.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Whoever has the gun, you see, gets to tell everybody else exactly what to do.  It's the American way.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I mean it!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Then you'd better fix your bayonet, because there aren't any bullets in the gun.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Where's the bullet?
